{{redirect-distinguish|Elrey|El Rey (disambiguation){{!}}El Rey|ElRay}} '''Elrey Borge Jeppesen''' (January 28, 1907 – November 26, 1996) was an American aviation pioneer noted for his contributions in the field of [[air navigation]]. He developed manuals and charts that allowed pilots to fly much more safely. He founded the [[Jeppesen|company that bears his name]] in 1934.
==Biography== [[Image:Jeppesen child.jpg|thumb|200px|Jeppesen (age 13 or less) as a youth (no later than 1920).]] Jeppesen was born on January 28, 1907, in [[Lake Charles, Louisiana]], [[United States]], [[North America]]. His parents were immigrants from [[Denmark]]. His father was a [[Cabinetry|cabinetmaker]]. He grew up in [[Odell, Oregon]], before moving to [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]].<ref name=OregonHall>{{cite journal |last=Bedell |first=Tom |year=2011 |title=2011 Oregon Hall of Fame |journal=Oregon Aviation Historical Society |publisher= |volume=20 |issue=2 |pages= |url=http://oregonaviation.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/2011_07.pdf}}</ref>
As a child, Jeppesen watched eagles flying for hours and flying became his obsession.<ref name="NY Times Obit">{{cite news|last=Thomas, Jr.|first=Robert|title=Elrey B. Jeppesen, Pilots' Friend, Dies at 89|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/28/us/elrey-b-jeppesen-pilots-friend-dies-at-89.html|accessdate=January 27, 2013|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=November 28, 1996}}</ref>
In 1921, then 14-year-old Jeppesen got his first taste of flying when a [[Barnstorming|barnstormer]] took him up in a [[Curtiss JN-4]] "Jenny" for a ten-minute flight for US$4 ({{Inflation|US|4|1921|fmt=eq}}).<ref name=Boeing>{{cite journal |url=http://www.boeing.com/news/frontiers/archive/2005/august/i_history.html |title=The early adventures of Captain Jepp |last=Dumovich |first=Eve |journal=Boeing Frontiers |year=2005 |volume=4 |issue=4}}</ref><ref name=Baird>{{cite web|url=http://airportjournals.com/Display.cfm?varID=0702007 |title=New Book Marks Jeppesenâ€™s 100th Birthday |author=Cary Baird |date=February 2007 |accessdate=August 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120627082136/http://airportjournals.com/Display.cfm?varID=0702007 |archivedate=June 27, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
In 1925, at the age of 18, Jeppesen joined [[Tex Rankin]]'s Flying Circus "as a ticket taker, a prop turner, a [[Wing walking|wing walker]] and an aerial acrobat".<ref name=Boeing/><ref name=DMAirfield>{{cite web |url=http://www.dmairfield.com/people/jeppesen_eb/index.html |title=Elrey Borge Jeppesen: Pioneer |publisher=Davis-Monthan Aviation Field Register |date=June 3, 2007 |accessdate=August 25, 2012}}</ref> He soloed after two hours and 15 minutes of flying lessons and purchased his own Jenny for $500,<ref name=Boeing/> using money borrowed from customers on his newspaper route.<ref name="NY Times Obit" /> For two years beginning in 1928, he worked for Fairchild Aerial Surveys, flying photographers over Mexico in a [[Airco DH.4|De Haviland DH-4]].<ref name=Boeing/><ref name=DMAirfield/> That same year, the United States government issued its first pilot's licenses; Jeppesen had Oregon's 27th license, and it was signed by [[Orville Wright]].<ref name="NY Times Obit" />
In 1930, Jeppesen joined [[United Airlines|Boeing Air Transport]] as an airmail pilot.<ref name=Boeing/> According to one source, on May 15, 1930, he was the pilot of the flight carrying the first [[Flight attendant|stewardess]], [[Ellen Church]].<ref name=Baird/> Heinrich Kubis had been the first male flight attendant in 1912.{{fact|date=April 2018}}
While airway beacons assisted aerial navigation on specific routes, most pilots at that time depended on [[dead reckoning]], generally using automobile road maps (such as those from oil companies or commercial mapmakers), railroad tracks and landmarks to find their way.<ref name=Boeing/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.coloradoaviationhistoricalsociety.org/bio_popup.asp?id=148 |title=Elrey B. Jeppesen: CAHS Honored in 1970 |publisher=Colorado Aviation Historical Society |accessdate=August 25, 2012}}</ref> Jeppesen purchased a ten-cent notebook and started writing down detailed notes about his routes.<ref name="NY Times Obit" /> He even climbed hills to determine their height and collected telephone numbers of farmers willing to provide weather reports.<ref name=DMAirfield/> Word got around about his "Little Black Book", and soon he was giving copies to his fellow pilots.<ref name=Boeing/>
In {{start date and age|1934|paren=y}}, as demand picked up, Jeppesen founded [[Jeppesen|Jeppesen & Co.]] in the basement of his [[Salt Lake City]] home to sell his information for US$10 ({{Inflation|US|10|1934|fmt=eq}}) a copy.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.boeing.com/news/frontiers/archive/2009/november/i_ca.pdf |title=Charting the course |last=Griffin |first=Dawsalee |journal=Boeing Frontiers |year=2009 |volume=8 |issue=7}}</ref>
On September 24, 1936, Jeppesen married his flight attendant, [[Nadine Jeppesen|Nadine Liscomb]].<ref name=Boeing/> She helped him run his company.{{fact|date=April 2018}}
On June 10, 1941, Jeppesen was involved in an accident at [[Denver Municipal Airport]]. While landing in a rainstorm, the United [[Douglas DC-3|DC-3]] aircraft overran the landing area, traveling through the airport boundary lights and into a {{convert|3|ft|m|sing=on|0|abbr=off}} ditch where the right landing gear failed. Neither the crew nor any of the 15 passengers were injured, but the aircraft itself sustained major damage.<ref name="CAA Accident Report">[http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?file&fn=8&name=*P%3A%5CDOT%5Cairplane%20accidents%5Cwebsearch%5C061041.pdf ]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://specialcollection.dotlibrary.dot.gov/Document?db=DOT-AIRPLANEACCIDENTS&query=(select+119)|title=DOT Special Library Collection, Aviation Accidents|last=|first=|date=|website=US DOT National Transportation Library|publisher=US Government|access-date=}}</ref>
In the 1940s, with the onset of [[World War II]], the United States Army and Navy kept Jeppesen busy supplying them with his charts. Jeppesen retired from United Airlines (into which Boeing Air Transport had merged) in 1954.<ref name=Boeing/>
In 1961, Jeppesen sold his company, staying on as chairman.<ref name=Boeing/>
On November 26, 1996, Jeppesen died at the age of 89.<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=E. B. Jeppesen, Pioneer Flier, Dies At Home |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=RM&p_theme=rm&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB4E6BD6F0B9541&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |quote=Elrey Borge Jeppesen, the pioneering pilot who charted the skies and made an indelible mark on aviation history, died at his home Tuesday. He was 89. ... |newspaper=[[Rocky Mountain News]] |date=November 27, 1996 |accessdate=2011-11-26 }}</ref>
==Legacy== The Jeppesen company continues to exist today, currently as a subsidiary of [[Boeing|Boeing Commercial Airplanes]], which acquired the business in October 2000.<ref name="jeppesen_company_timeline">[http://www.jeppesen.com/company/about/timeline.jsp Historic timeline of the Jeppesen company]</ref>
There is a {{convert|16|ft|m|adj=on}} statue of Jeppesen, by the artist George Lundeen, in the center of the main terminal at Denver International Airport. The main terminal is also named in his honor.<ref name="NY Times Obit" /> Around the base of the statue is the accolade: â€³Airmail Pilot - Airline Captain - Wing Walker - Air Navigation Pioneer - Barnstormer - Air Safety Pioneer - Businessman - Instructor".
The [[Museum of Flight]] holds the Elrey B. Jeppesen Collection in its archives. A facsimile of the Little Black Book is also on display in the museum's galleries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.museumofflight.org/collections/museum-archives |title=Museum Archives |publisher=Museum of Flight}}</ref>

''These We Honor: The International Aerospace Hall of Fame''. Donning Co. Publishers, 2006. [[International Standard Book Number|ISBN]] [[Special:BookSources/978-1-57864-397-4|978-1-57864-397-4]].</ref> * Oregon Aviation Hall of Honor<ref name="or_av_hoh">The [http://sprucegoose.org/aircraft_artifacts/honor.html Oregon Aviation Hall of Honor], established by Oregon Department of Aviation in 2003, is located at the [[Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum]] in McMinnville, Oregon.</ref> * OX5 Aviation Hall of Fame * NBAA Meritorious Service Award * [[Edward Warner Award]], 1995
